Incident.Summary: Multiple complainants reported their children's bus driver slammed on the brakes and cause multiple injuries.

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
Body Worn Camera Operational.

SCENE PROCESSING:
            Seven MSP Form 76, Written Statements, from multiple complainants. Two digital photographs of a victim’s injuries, Saige Hong. One digital photograph of a text message from the victim, Saige Hong.

PHYSICAL EVIDENCE:
            Seven (7) MSP Form 76, Written Statements.
            Two (2) digital photographs of a victim’s injuries.
            One (1) digital photograph of a text message from a victim.

NARRATIVE:
            On September 25, 2023, at 2028 hours, while on duty, I responded to the lobby of the Leonardtown Barrack “T” located at, 23200 Leonard Hall Dr Leonardtown, St. Mary’s County, Maryland 20650 for the report an assault.

            I made contact with the complainants, who were identified by their Maryland Driver’s License as Justin James Barlow (W/M DOB 01/19/1981) and Amy Elizabeth Barlow (W/F DOB 10/26/1976). Justin and Amy both advised, on September 15, 2023 between 1545 and 1600 hours, their daughter got off a St. Mary’s County Public School Bus #610 with a bloody nose. They identified their daughter as Madyson Nicole Barlow (W/F DOB 09/30/2015). Madyson told her parents the school bus driver was yelling at all of the children on the bus to sit in their seats. Madyson told her parents the bus driver became angry and slammed on the brakes. Madyson thrusted forward striking her face on the seat in front of her, causing her nose to bleed. Justin and Amy advised since the incident occurred, Madyson has had trouble sleeping at night and  has had nightmares about the incident.

            Justin and Amy advised they have had multiple problems with this school bus driver during the last school year. They advised the school bus driver has yelled at the children before, threatening to duct tape the children to the seat. They advised on one occasion the school bus driver pulled over on the side of the road. The school bus driver opened the doors to the bus and threated to make the kids walk home. Justin and Amy made several complainants last year to Jeff Thompson, the Director of the Department of Transportation. Justin and Amy advised their complainants were dismissed by Thompson. Justin and Amy along with several other parents filed a complaint against the bus driver for the incident that occurred on September 15, 2023. Amy advised she received an email on September 18, 2023 from Vean Barr, Driver Trainer of the Department of Transportation, stating they are investigating the incident and will take corrective actions accordingly.

            Justin and Amy advised they filed a request to view the video surveillance from the school bus. On September 25, 2023 they reviewed the video surveillance. They advised the footage shows that there is nothing in front of the school bus, while it is traveling down the road, which would cause the driver to slam on the brakes. They advised the footage shows the school bus driver yelling at the kids and suddenly “brake checks” the kids out of anger. They advised the video footage shows the school buses speed, which suddenly goes from 37mph to 27mph in a second. They advised the footage shows Madyson hitting her face on the seat in front of her. Justin and Amy both completed an MSP Form 76, Written Statement.

            On September 26, 2023, at approximately 0900 hours, two more complainants responded to the Leonardtown Barrack “T”. The complainants were identified by their Maryland Driver’s License as Corey Liberato Ianiero (W/M DOB 06/04/1988) and Laura Christine Ianiero (W/F DOB 04/16/1987). They identified their children as Maddox Scott Ianiero (W/M DOB 08/16/2015) and Lennox Nicola Ianiero (W/M DOB 04/30/2018). They advised their children both ride on St. Mary’s County Public School Bus #610. They advised on September 15, 2023, at approximately 1600 hours, they observed Madyson come off the school bus with a bloody nose. They advised their children, Maddox and Lennox told them the school bus driver started yelling at them for being too loud. Maddox and Lennox told their parents the school bus driver was angry and “brake checked” the bus. They advised everyone on the bus slammed into the seat in front of them.

            Corey and Laura advised they first filed a complainant against the bus driver last school year. They advised the bus driver threatened to duct tape all of the children to the seats and threatened to make all of the kids walk home. They advised their complaints were dismissed. They advised their children continued to complain about the school bus driver’s angry behavior for the rest of the school year.

            On September 26, 2023, Corey and Laura advised they reviewed the surveillance video of the incident that occurred on September 15, 2023. They advised they reviewed the footage with Charles Eible, Head of Safety and Security. They advised the footage shows nothing in front of the school bus which would cause the driver to slam on his brakes. They advised the footage shows the school bus driver yelling at the children. The bus driver then slams on his brakes. They advised they can clearly see Maddox hit his head on the seat in front of him.  They advised the school bus speed suddenly goes from 37mph to 27 mph in a second. Corey and Laura both completed an MSP Form 76, Written Statement.

            On September 26, 2023 at approximately 1015 hours, a fifth complainant responded to the Leonardtown Barrack “T”. The complainant was identified by her Maryland Driver’s License Kristen Lauren Schulz (W/F DOB 02/25/1987). Schulz advised her son, who she identified as Graham Schultz (W/M DOB 06/09/2017), got off St. Mary’s County Public School Bus #610 on September 15, 2023 at approximately 1600 hours. Graham told Kristen the bus driver was yelling at the children on the bus and then slammed on the brakes. Graham told Kristen many of the kids hit their face directly on the seat in front of them. Kristen advised their neighbor Madyson, was bleeding from her nose as result of the bus driver slamming on the brakes.

            Kristen advised the school bus driver has a history of erratic behavior. Kirsten advised complainants were filed against the school bus driver last year, however their complainants were dismissed. Kristen advised she filed a complainant along with several other parents about the incident that occurred on September 15, 2023. Kristen advised Thompson, replied back to one of the many complainants via telephone and advised the incident was blown out of proportion. Kristen advised after reviewing he surveillance video from the bus, it shows multiple kids “slamming their faces/heads into the seat in front of them.” Kristen advised the footage shows there was no objects, cars, or animals in front of the bus to cause the driver to slam on the brakes. The footage shows the buses speed going from 37mph to 27mph in a second. Kristen completed an MSP Form 76, Written Statement.

            On September 26, 2023, at approximately 1403 hours, a sixth complainant responded to the Leonardtown Barrack “T”. The complainant was identified by her Maryland Driver’s License as Amber Lynn O’Leary (W/F DOB 05/14/1993). Amber identified her two children as Kerrick O’Leary and Langston O’Leary. Amber both of her children ride St. Mary’s County Public School Bus #610. Amber advised both of her kids were riding the bus on September 15, 2023 at approximately 1600 hours, when the school bus driver was yelling at children on the bus and slammed on his brakes. Amber advised both of her children slammed into the seat in front of them. Amber advised Kerrick has had several headaches due to him hitting his head on the seat in front of him. Amber advised she did not observe any bruising on Kerrick. Amber advised both of her children were both scared during the incident, and do want to ride the school bus anymore.

            Amber advised there was incident last school year involving the same school bus driver. Amber advised the school bus driver, threatened to duct tape all of the kids to the seat. The school bus driver also pulled onto the side of the road and threatened to make all of the kids walk home. Amber advised complaints were filed against the bus driver, however the complainants were dismissed.

            Amber advised she went to review the video surveillance from the bus, which shows the school bus driver yelling at the children on the bus. Amber advised the school bus driver then “brake checks” the bus causing the children to hit their faces/heads on the seat in front of them. Amber advised the footage shows there is no objects, cars, or animals in front of the bus to cause the driver to suddenly slam on the brakes. Amber advised the buses speed drastically slows down in a second. Amber advised it is not safe for the school bus driver to continue driving. Amber completed an MSP Form 76, Written Statement.

            On September 26, 2023, at approximately 1422 hours, a seventh complainant responded to the Leonardtown Barrack “T”. The complainant was identified by her Maryland Driver’s License as Brandi Michelle Hong (W/F DOB 01/27/1979). Hong identified her child as Saige Hong (W/F DOB 01/13/2013). Brandi advised Saige rides on St. Mary’s County Public School Bus #610. Brandi advised on September 15 ,2023 at approximately 1600 hours, Saige got the school bus in tears. Saige told Brandi that the school bus driver was yelling at the children on the bus because they were being too loud. Saige told Brandi the school bus driver then “braked checked” the bus causing the children to hit their faces on the seat in front of them. Brandi advised Saige wears glasses, which when she hit her face, her glasses pushed further into her face causing more pain. Brandi did note, Saige’s glasses did not break. Brandi advised Saige got off the bus, with a lump on her forehead, which later turned into a bruise. I did obtain two digital photographs from Brandi of Saige’s injuries. Brandi also provided me with a digital photograph of a text thread between her and Saige. In the text thread, Saige is explaining to Brandi what happened on the bus prior to her getting off at the bus stop.

            Brandi advised she reviewed the video surveillance from the school bus, which shows the bus driver yelling at the children. Brandi advised the footage shows the school bus driver “brake checking” the bus. Brandi advised the children hit their faces on the seat in front of them, while the bus driver continued to yell at the children. Brandi advised the school buses speed goes from 37mph to 26mph. Brandi advised there was no objects, cars, or animals in front of the bus to cause the bus driver to slam on the brakes. Brandi completed an MSP Form 76, Written Statement.

            All of the complainants and children’s information was relayed to the St. Mary’s County Child Protective Services (CPS). Brittany Morgan from CPS has been assigned to the case. Further Interviews with victims/complainants have been set up by CPS for Thursday September 28, 2023.

            The St. Mary’s County States Attorney’s Office has sent Subpoena request to the Department of Transportation for the bus video surveillance and to identify the school bus driver for bus #610

I request this case to remain open, pending further investigation.
All events occurred in St. Mary’s County, Maryland.

Narrative:

   On 9/29/2023 at 1330 hours Sgt T. Newcomer # 6072 CED-Central-South and I responded to the Board of Education for St. Marys County, MD to meet with the Director of School Safety, Charles Eible.
  
   Upon arriving, Mr. Eible escorted us to his office where he had the Bus’s cameras in a multi-cam view displayed on a television. Mr. Eible played the video multiple times with audio so I and Sgt. Newcomer could view it. While viewing the video, I observed the video started at 1606 hours and the bus appeared to be traveling on Pin Cushion Road, the cross street was not identified during the portion of the video I viewed.
  
   At 1607 hours the driver applies the brakes, the bus’s speed drop from approximately 36 mph to 27 mph.  As a result, of the abrupt application of the brakes, I did not observe any actions that would have caused any obvious injury to the students. Due to the children's age, height/size some of the children are not fully visible on camera due to the height of the seat in front of them. I did not hear any screaming or crying and there was no obvious, audible/verbal mention of anyone being injured. After applying the brakes, the driver does not accelerate but continues to slowly come to a stop. At this time he was not at a specific stop to drop off children, he stopped so he could attempt to get the children to quiet down. You then heard the driver, yell for the children/students to sit down, be quiet. He then advised he would take the children back to school and they would not get home until 5 o’ clock. He also advised he would write or have the students written up. After speaking to the children, the driver accelerates, travels a short distance then stops to let a child off of the bus.
  
   After viewing the video, Mr. Eible advised the driver is a contracted employee through the Department of Transportation and referred us to Mr. Jeff Thompson for any further inquiries regarding the driver/bus. Mr. Eible did advise the driver is no longer covering/driving that elementary route and he believes he was moved to a High School route. Mr. Eible advised the initial complaint was made by email to them on 9/15/2023.
  
   On 10/4/2023 at 1300 hours I responded to the Circuit Court for St. Marys County to meet with ASA S. Proctor regarding this incident. Sgt. Newcomer and Cpl. Posey, CED-Central South were also in attendance during the meeting. ASA Proctor received numerous items relevant to this investigation as a result of a grand jury subpoena from the SMCPS. While in the office, all parties watched the bus surveillance video numerous times and through multiple camera views.  After watching the video, ASA Proctor advised she would not recommend criminal charges at this time against the driver.

Case closed.

Below is a synopsis of interviews completed by CED Central South. These interviews copies are going to be obtained from Saint Mary's Department of Child Services. 

Interview #1:

    On 09/28/2023, I was present to observe the forensic interview of Sage Hong reference to case number 23-MSP-033832. During this incident, it was conveyed that Sage, who is 12 years old, was on Saint Mary’s County school bus 610 which was operated by John Wathen. While on the school bus on or about September 15th, 2023, Wathen is alleged to have “brake checked” the bus causing students to be thrown throughout the bus.

    The interview was conducted by Brittany Morgan of the Saint Mary’s County Department of Social Services. Brittany began the interview at approximately 1040 hours. Present in the room for the interview was Morgan and Sage. Myself, Cpl. C. Ditoto and Lisa Sheehan of the Saint Mary’s County Department of Social Services were present in the viewing room. Sage’s parents, Brandi Michelle Hong (W/F DOB: 1/27/1979) and Joseph Michael Hong (W/M DOB: 07/21/1978) were present in the building during the interview.

    Brittany began the interview with Sage in rapport building. Sage appeared comfortable speaking to Brittany. Sage stated on this particular day her bus was running late. She stated all the students boarded the bus in a normal fashion. The students boarded the bus at Benjamin Banneker elementary. Upon boarding the bus, students were acting in a normal fashion. However, no one appeared to be yelling or screaming. Sage stated Wathen yelled, “Shut up Carter” to one of the students before slamming on the brakes of the bus. Upon slamming on the brakes of the bus, multiple students suffered involuntary bodily movements due to the inertia of the vehicle. During this involuntary movement, Sage’s head came in contact with the seat directly in front of her seat. Sage described the seat as being a normal bus seat which she described as hollow in the middle outlined by a metal bar. Sage’s face came in contact with the metal bar. This contact caused Sage’s glasses to be pushed into her face. The end result was Sage suffering a bruise on her face, between her eyes, just above her nose. Sage also stated a little girl on the bus suffered a bloody nose.  The interview concluded with no further investigative information being provided.

    I made contact with Brandi and Joseph. Brandi and Joseph both described the injuries sustained by their daughter as concerning. However, it was apparent the parents were both extremely frustrated with the response of the school administration. Brandi and Joseph had not seen the video of the incident, however, were aware that a video was available. Brandi and Joseph were also told by other parents what was on the video and were concerned about this. Brandi and Joseph both stated this has been an ongoing issue with Wathen and the students. Although attempts have been made to notify the school, nothing has been done by the school to correct what the parents viewed as an ongoing issue. Brandi and Joseph were provided contact information for the State Police as well as reissued the case number. 

    This concludes my portion of the investigation.

    All events occurred in Saint Mary’s County, MD.

Interview #2:

    On September 28, 2023, at approximately 1300 hours a Forensic Interview was conducted at the St. Mary’s County Child Advocacy Center for one of the juvenile victims (Madisyn Barlow 7 year old). The interview was conducted by Brittany Morgan of Child Protective Services and TFC Ruggles and Cpl. C. DiToto were present and observed the interview.

    In relation to this incident which occurred on September 15, 2023, the victim advised she was aboard the school bus which was to be transporting her home at the end of the school day. She stated the bus was driven by “Mr. Wathen”. The victim said, Mr. Wathen stopped the bus and let kids off and as he was accelerating from the stop he began to yell at other kids on the bus because “everyone was being loud.” The victim stated Mr. Wathen yelled at the juveniles on the bus to sit down and be quite and shortly thereafter the bus abruptly slowed speed causing several juveniles and their belongings to be thrown forward either into the seats in front of them or into the isle. The victim advised prior to the bus abruptly slowing speed she was “itching” the inside of her nose and there was no blood in her nose; however after the bus abruptly slowed its speed she “itched” the inside of her nose again and this time there was a small amount of blood in her nose. The victim said after she got off the bus she was picked up by her father, Justin James Barlow (W/M DOB: 01/19/1981) who she informed of the incident. The victim advised approximately two days later she was playing soccer and for no reason her nose started bleeding profusely, and she was unable to continue to play soccer as her nose would not stop bleeding. The victim made several other statements about previous issues of Mr. Wathen being rude and discourteous to juveniles on the bus.

    TFC Ruggles, Cpl. C. DiToto, Lisa Sheehan (CPS/CAC) and Brittany Morgan spoke to the juvenile’s parents, Justin and Amy Elizabeth Barlow (W/F DOB: 10/26/1976). They voiced their concerns on how they did not feel the incident was handled appropriately by the St. Mary’s County Board of Education or the St. Mary’s County Sheriff’s Office. Justin confirmed his daughter did have a small amount of blood coming from her nose upon exiting the school bus on 9/15/23. Justin further confirmed on 9/17/23 his daughter had a sudden and unexplained nose bleed while playing soccer, and it took several minutes and multiple tissues/paper towels in order to stop and clean the bleeding. Justin advised at this time he has not yet taken his daughter to the doctor to see if she has any sort of internal injury to her nose which may have been the cause for the nose bleed. Justin and Amy both advised of several other incidents of Mr. Wathen being rude, discourteous and otherwise unprofessional to the juveniles on the bus which they were aware of. Amy also provided investigators with a photograph of Mr. Wathen to assist in his identification. Investigators explained to Justin and Amy, once all evidence is gathered it will be provided to the St. Mary’s County States Attorney’s Office, and it will be up to them to determine if there is sufficient evidence to believe a crime occurred and charges should be pursued. 

Interview #3 & #4:
 

  On 9/28/2023 at approximately 1430 hours, Cpl. Posey responded to the St. Mary’s County Child Advocacy center at 21783 North Coral Drive Lexington Park, MD 20653, for forensic interviews of two children. The youths were involved in an incident, on their School bus, where the bus driver was said to have slammed on the brakes due to disruptive activity on the bus. Cpl. Posey made contact with Mrs. O’leary who is the mother of the two boys to be interviewed. Cpl. Posey developed a rapport with Mrs. O’leary to help her feel more comfortable with her boys being interviewed outside her presence. Mrs. O’leary agreed to have the boys individually interviewed by Child Protective Services investigator Brittany Morgan. 

  The first interview conducted was with Kerrick O’leary. During the course of this interview the youth advised he was on the bus and the bus driver was yelling. The reason given for the bus drivers outburst was that a friend of his got in trouble. The youth advised the bus driver slammed on brakes and everybody on the bus went forward. The youth stated he hit his face on the seat in front of him and the right side of his head was hurt. The youth identified the bus driver as Mr. Wathen.

  The second interview was conducted with Langston O’Leary also by Brittany Morgan. During the course of this interview, the youth identified the bus driver as Mr. Wathen. The youth stated “Carter” was not in his seat and he was saying bad words. The youth stated the bus driver slammed on the brakes, “Sage” glasses got smushed, and “Maddie” got a bloody nose. The youth continued stating the bus driver said he was going to make all the kids walk home. The youth advised he did not sustain any injuries during this incident. The youth stated his only concern was that the bus driver would come back to work and do the same thing again.

These interviews were audibly and visually recorded by the Child advocacy center. This report is intended to summarize the interviews. Access to interview footage is available to authorized personnel. 

Interview #5:
    On 10/4/2023 at approximately 1000 hours, Cpl. Posey responded to the St. Mary’s County Child Advocacy center at 21783 North Coral Drive Lexington Park, MD 20653, for forensic interviews of two children. The youths were involved in an incident, on their School bus, where the bus driver was said to have slammed on the brakes due to disruptive activity on the bus. Cpl. Posey observed the interview of a child who was on the bus from the Schulz family, during the interview the following was observed, Schultz advised the Bus Driver's Name was Mr. Wathen, Schulz  advised Wathen stopped the bus and stated if you don’t be quiet you’re going to walk home. Schulz heard kids laughing. Schulz stated his friend got her glasses broke and had a bloody nose. Schulz said kids were being loud and screaming. Schulz stated Mr. Wathen didn’t really do anything, but he stomped on the brakes. That concluded this interview.


Interview #6 & #7:

    On 10/4/2023 at approximately 0850 hours, Sgt. Newcomer responded to the St. Mary's child Advocacy center at 21783 North Coral Drive Lexington Park, MD 20653, for forensic interviews of two children. The two children were involved in an incident on their school bus where the brakes were applied causing rapid deceleration of the school bus. The two children were from the Ianeiro family, and they were transported to the facility by their mother, Laura Ianiero. The two children who were interviewed advised the bus driver hit the brakes causing other children to make contact with the seat in front of them. The children advised they didn't sustain any injuries, but they think other children on the bus did. A full interview report will be attached to this case file. After the interview Sgt. Newcomer made contact with Mrs. Ianiero, her main concern was that the bus driver be punished, and he is removed from driving their children to school. I advised to Mrs. Ianiero that as the Maryland State Police we only investigate if a crime occurred and her chief complaint would have to be taken to the Saint Mary's County Board of Education and the Saint Mary's County Department of Transportation. Mrs. Ianiero was receptive and I advised the St. Mary's County States Attorney's Office would keep her up to date with the case as it progresses.

     On 10/4/23 investigators with MSP CED Central South met with Saint Mary’s County Assistant State’s Attorney Sarah Proctor to review the case. Proctor sent a legal request to St. Mary’s County Public Schools to receive the footage of the bus incident and related documents. Proctor received the supplies on 10/3/23. Proctor watched the video of the bus incident along with investigators and determined this incident does contain substance for a criminal charge. Proctor advised she will have the alleged victim's parents come into the St. Mary’s County ASA office and she will notify them of her findings. This case remains with the MSP Leonardtown Barrack, and this concludes CED Central South’s involvement in the matter.

    Case Closed.
